column1: Before 1 January 2021, will the People's Liberation Army (PLA) and/or People’s Armed Police (PAP) be mobilized in Hong Kong?
column6: ['Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']

Hong Kong is still relevant due to its open financial markets and connection to International instruments and China needs to internationalise its currency. China now controls Hong Kong politically, introduced its security law and ignored any treaties, so an invasion of armed forces is probably not necessary. http://www.iberchina.org/files/2017/china_2021_chatham.pdf

Hong Kong protest aftermath: what is top cop’s biggest challenge? - South China Morning Post. https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3111717/aftermath-hong-kong-protests-top-cops-biggest Mon, 30 Nov 2020 00:00:18 GMT Pretty chilling: > These days, he said, residents from all walks of life spread untrue posts and anti-police messages on an unprecedented scale over social media. > As of the end of October, 10,148 people aged 11 to 84 had been arrested in connection with the social unrest and almost a quarter had been prosecuted. Of the 726 people already dealt with, over four-fifths were convicted, with the stiffest penalty being a four-year prison sentence. > Of the 124 letters sent by police to media to refute false or biased reports, 105 (85 per cent), went to Chinese-language newspaper Apple Daily, which regularly splashed reports alleging police brutality or wrongdoing on its front page. > Tang said: “A powerful person who controls a media organisation openly requested foreign countries to sanction Hong Kong and China. Everyone knows about it.” > He refrained from naming Apple Daily founder Jimmy Lai Chee-ying when he accused “media forces” of sabotaging police efforts to enforce the law. Lai was arrested in August under the national security law for alleged collusion with foreign forces.

"a year ago, hundreds of thousands of people joined unauthorised demonstrations calling for full democracy. Now only the very brave are prepared to protest without police approval ... Many of the activists involved in the unrest that swept Hong Kong for months last year are keeping their heads down ... So far, however, the [new national security] law has been sparingly applied. Hundreds of people have been arrested for protest-related offences since the central government in Beijing imposed the act on June 30th ... Only about 30 people have been arrested under the new law." https://www.economist.com/china/2020/10/08/hong-kongs-new-security-law-is-being-applied-sparingly-so-far

It seems that the students have more to gain by initiating an event that would initiate mobilization than the government, so if I assign a 50% probability for students and a 10% for a government initiated event , I'm calculating about 35%. If the students get more desperate as the government gets closer to full unification, or the students swell and get more support from 'common folk' or external support (British, USA, ?) probabilities of government action would be expected to go up. I don't think the student probability can go much higher
Activity is about normal (for Hong Kong). National Day celebrations did not massive protests. Backing down my probability for now.

major Chinese holiday coming up, refugees at sea trying to escape, Chinese gov (?) may be feeling their control slipping and need to show some control. Will protesters overplay their hand or lose control? How will India play into the question? The pot is starting to bubble. Interesting.

From the Economist “ Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, celebrated the city’s “return to stability” at a flag-raising ceremony for China’s National Day. Hundreds of police patrolled the streets, looking for signs of a banned pro-democracy demonstration that failed to materialise. Protests had been planned against the National Security Law and the arrest of 12 people who attempted to flee to Taiwan.”

"Millions of Hong Kongers were supposed to vote in legislative council elections on Sunday. But in July, Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam delayed the elections for one year under the guise of a coronavirus public health threat. So instead of casting ballots, hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators took to the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday ... Sunday's protest was relatively small. However, the number of arrests was similar to that seen during last year's large-scale demonstrations ... Galileo Cheng, the social affairs executive for the Hong Kong Catholic Institution Staff Association, told DW that those who were still willing to join yesterday's protest, despite the national security law and the ban on public gathering, were well-prepared and more aggressive than normal protesters ... many peaceful protesters have been deterred by the pandemic and new rules not permitting demonstrations." https://www.dw.com/en/chinas-influence-changing-hong-kong-protests/a-54842597

"Police fired rounds of pepper balls at protesters in Hong Kong on Sunday and arrested almost 300 after demonstrators took to the streets to oppose the postponement of legislative elections and a new national security law imposed by China ... Anti-government demonstrations have declined this year mainly because of limits on group gatherings, imposed to counter the spread of coronavirus, and the security law, which punishes actions China sees as subversive, secessionist, terrorist or colluding with foreign forces." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-security-protests/hong-kong-police-fire-pepper-balls-at-protesters-opposed-to-election-delay-new-law-idUSKBN25X0AX

After much discussion in class about the rarity of Chinese military actions, and the steady downward trend of my fellow forecasters, I'm revising my submission down. I haven't had time to do any additional research, so this is really a vote of faith in the wisdom of crowds... the protests have been ongoing for more than a year, and China hasn't used military intervention to end them. As stated in my original forecast, and voiced by fellow forecasters, it seems likely China has refrained from military intervention in order to refute global political pressure with regards to its poor record on human rights issues... but I'm leaving a window open for the possibility that a triggering event in mainland China could lead to a crackdown in which China re-asserts control in Hong Kong in order to quell similar actions in China.
Creeping down as time moves on, it's unlikely to happen
Tweaking down forecast a bit as activity seems to be quelled for the moment.

The police have it under control and have broken the protest spirit. They are systemically arresting - possibly preemptively - all leaders. The police is now on the front door. There is no need to escalate and ask China for assistance.
Lowering my forecast again - seems to be very low chance that China will mobilize PLP/PAP in Hong Kong to avoid bad media coverage & they haven't done do since 1997 (HK independence).

I was just randomly thinking about this question. Why would China need to mobilize the PLA in HK? It did not need to use this option when the Legco was stormed and universities where under siege in 2019. With the new laws in place, this kind of popular uprising has become a lot less likely. So why provoke the general population, the United States, etc. by doing something so radical, if the HK police are perfectly capable of roughing up protesters, and the courts now provide a tool to lock up people indefinitely?
My theory is China is letting COVID in Hong Kong prevent mass protests in place of needing PLA / PAP.

China has refrained from military intervention for more than seven months, likely due to a desire to mitigate global political pressure to respect human rights. But China may also be feeling mounting internal pressure to "get this under control" in order to discourage nascent internal protest movements. If there is some internal triggering event (dissident arrest, political event, etc.) that generates greater support inside China for the Hong Kong protestors, China may feel compelled to act to shut down the protests.

The election may have some influence on this question, so am hesitant to give much more than a 50/50 probability. I believe China will have as many facts and best estimates before making a no return decision.
Pandemic often deeps societal points of strain and Hong Kong may be embolden by the other protests around the world. If protest resume we can assume the PLA will be mobilized.
This prediction is a guess.

I am going to assume that the question is to determine whether a mainland Chinese overwhelming force will take over and take control (officially) from the Hong Kong authorities. According to reports the PLA and PAP already have a presence in Hong Kong in either a support or monitoring effort. Us military power, UK ex-colonial power, Australia regional strategic power and Canada are starting to increase their pressure on China by restricting visas, ceasing extradition treaties and offering resident/citizen visas to Hong Kong people. The U.S. is withdrawing special country status from China that diminishes its role as a global financial hub. Huawei telecommunications equipment is being deleted or restricted as a supplier to the Five eyes intelligence group. The credibility of the Chinese government has been eroded due its handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Vietnam have been treated with disdain by China in a dispute over the South China sea islands showing the Chinese governments influence as a superpower. It is a matter of honour for China to reclaim Hong Kong as it was taken by a dominant colonial power and funded by drug money by supplying opium to their people to subjugate them. China now has the power to take control of its own destiny and a lessening need for HK. Hong Kong is still a financial hub, albeit diminishing due to rise of Shanghai and with Singapore in the background; China will need to dismantle the Hong Kong administration step by step. An overt invasion of Hong Kong by the PLA/PAP would be a massive PR disaster (Tiananmen Square) and is not necessary. China has the power; HK has no military force of its own and can be assimilated into China step by step and at China’s timing. The overwhelming force is already there, a PR disaster in the glare of the World’s media is not required. A possible weak link of China is the number of students it has studying in the West and their immediate dismissal and relocation to China might cause a problem. Australia 260,000; 369,000 US; 120,000 UK. (2019) Therefore, I propose a 10% chance of full mobilisation at his stage, although a surreptitious activity could be currently happening by the PAP.
No need for them anymore.

The announcement drew immediate protests from opposition leaders who warned that it would imperil the rule of law in Hong Kong ... The announcement of such far-reaching changes may reignite the huge street marches seen in Hong Kong last year, which demonstrated the breadth of antigovernment sentiment. That new security law is going into effect as early as September according NYT. If HK doesn't get its protestors in line by then, I think Beijing is going to use the opportunity to stamp out any political independence HK has left, starting with protests. HK's pro-democracy protest are essentially a variation on the theme of the five poisons, which China see as anethema to its long term interest. Unless HK finds a way to calm protestors - one way or the other - the PLA/PAP are likely to enter the fray.

The question asks whether there will be any active engagement between the PLA or PAP and Hong Kong protesters within the next seven months. Firstly, we should note that neither the PLA nor the PAP have ever been used in Hong Kong since the handover. Any change of this policy would cause domestic and international outrage in light of the 'one country, two systems' principle. Furthermore, China, conscious of its soft power, will be keen to avoid any Tiananmen-style images going around the world. However, engagement by either the PLA or PAP would not necessarily be as violent as the Tiananmen massacre. They could simply act as reinforcements for the Hong Kong Police Force (HKPF). As Carrie Lam has said, the HKPF has been 'outnumbered' in recent protests. These comments, in addition to comments by the PRC that it would 'not sit idly by' have created a rhetoric that opens the door to a future mobilisation of the PLA or PAP in Hong Kong. Considering that China wants to be seen as a responsible actor, the only real motivation for such a mobilisation would be continued and out of control protests. The recent actions by the PRC and Hong Kong legislatures provide ample reason for such protests. China has doubled the size of its contingent in Hong Kong, which notably now includes the PAP, which has been used in similar situations in Tibet and Xinjiang (the major difference lying in the fact that Hong Kong is a SAR). Mobilisation of these forces would, under the current rule of law, have to be requested by the Hong Kong government; a possible scenario, considering Carrie Lam's allegiance to the PRC and her comments on the HKPF being outnumbered. Lastly, the role of Covid-19 should be understood. Amidst the ongoing crisis countries have turned inwards, providing an opportunity for Beijing to move forward on some of its key ambitions with a weaker international backlash. Evaluating all of these arguments, 35% at this time seems adequate.

The CCP knows deploying the PLA or PAP into Hong Kong is a historically significant red line that is likely to cause further unification of political resistance and increase participation from those that would stay on the sidelines. Deploying these forces shatters any facade of "one state, two systems." Furthermore, widespread political protests will be hard this year, even as things open back up in Hong Kong. While the requirement to wear masks could make protestors feel more protected, the CCP may already be employing software that allows facial recognition even through masks (https://www.digitaltrends.com/news/china-megvii-facial-recognition-masks-coronvirus-hong-kong/ ; https://qz.com/1803737/chinas-facial-recognition-tech-can-crack-masked-faces-amid-coronavirus/).

Reversing. Coronavirus concerns might keep crowds off the streets. China has waited this long to send in those forces. Sentiment of support for peaceful demonstration is there but not for violence among the population.

It is highly unlikely that the PRC will utilize PLA and/or PAP troops in Hong Kong (10%). Thus far, Hong Kong's police force (or counter-protesters) has effectively contained the demonstrations. With only a handful of fatal casualties to date, there seems to be no need for China's more robust military forces to be mobilized in HK. Xi Jinping remembers well the results of armed forces being mobilized to quell demonstrations in Tiananmen Square and hopes to avoid that at all costs. Although the PAP has been successful with its operations in Xinjiang and Tibet its mobilization in a Special Administrative Region (SAR) such as HK would represent a more real and symbolic violation of its own "One Country, Two Systems" policy. China's economy is slowing and the PRC is currently scrambling to address its Coronavirus population. Damaging its reputation with HK, especially after it received support from the US President, might have disastrous blowback on its economy via trade. It still has to iron out trade deals with the US as well. There are many variables regarding the US general election this year, so any hasty moves that would cause President Trump to criticize China might manifest themselves for 4 more years (if he is re-elected in 2020).
